messageBody:
amd64_hacker:

I believe that the guiding light on joining letters should be
legibility. If it is clear what the word is then you have found an
acceptable solution. If the letters are joined in such a way, that it
could lead to confusion, then the word needs to be joined differently
or, perhaps, not joined at all. I haven't taken time to look, but I
believe the QS manual has an example of the word "pity" written with a
half-letter "tea" folled by "it." This wouldn't work with the American
pronunciation as we would use "eat" at the end, but it works fine with
the British pronunciation so I am not sure why you dismissed that
possibility.

Regarding your example of "Indy", I don't believe it makes a difference
to legibility whether the letters are joined at the bottom or the top.
It may be preferable to not join "day" and "eat" simply because the
letters are clearer when not joined, especially in handwriting. If the
letters are carefully formed, however, there is a shift in the curve
from "day" to "eat" (concave to convex viewed from the end of the word)
which should make it apparent what the letters are. If there is any
doubt, a small "step" as suggested in the QS man. could be used to
separate the two letters.

It seems to me that a "style guide" for printed text would be different
than one intended for handwriting. The latter should permit more
flexibility.

Regarding the use of abbreviations: I have no idea what "YMMV" is
supposed to mean, pointing out the danger to communication that
abbreviations can cause. I might think it a Roman numeral except that
"Y" isn't one :-) Only if an abbreviation is in wide-spread use with
an unequivocal meaning would it be safe to use. Otherwise, it just
slows the reader down or brings him to a halt while he ponders the
meaning of some unfamiliar abbreviation, and for what -- the savings of
a few pen or key strokes. In other words, an unknown abbreviation,
causes the very opposite of its intention -- instead of saving time for
both writer and reader, it only saves the writer's time and hinders
communication with the reader.

Paige


amd64_hacker wrote:

> [snip]
> Personally I'm for abbreviations in all texts.
> It seems to me that since QS is meant to be 'heard' it shouldn't matter
> how the word is written but how it is read.
> As you said it's personal, so YMMV.
>
>
> About half height letters, I have to agree that they are part of what
> makes QS look so pretty on paper.
> The trouble is which combinations to use, obviously a half height TEA
> followed by IT is out of the question, but which other combinations
> should be avoided?
>
> Also what do you do when you have several alternative ways of writing a
> word?
> Take for example the word 'indy': IT, NO, DAY, EAT (I think I have that
> right).
> You can write it using only the normal forms so that you join the IT,
> NO, DAY at their tops.
> Or you can use the alternate NO and half height DAY and join them all at
> the bottom.
> Also do you join DAY and EAT in either case?
>
> Again this is a personal thing but perhaps a few rules of thumb could be
> thrashed out? A sort of style guide for QS?
>
> Sorry it took me so long to write this email, but I've finally found a
> few hours to dedicate to folders other than my inbox. :)
>
